results.title: We did it!: Western Australia
results.creator_credit: Keith Gow, Elisabeth Knight, National Aboriginal Employment Development Committee and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “On the job (A)”.
Shows Aboriginal people in Western Australia talking about how they got their jobs, what they like about them and giving tips for other job seekers. Includes a student enrolled nurse, a teacher’s aide, a beautician, a horticulturalist and a park ranger.
Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: We did it!: South Australia
results.creator_credit: Keith Gow, Elisabeth Knight, National Aboriginal Employment Development Committee and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “On the job (A)”.
Shows Aboriginal people at work in South Australia, talking about how they got their jobs, what they like about them and giving tips for other job seekers. Includes a fisheries officer, an apprentice diesel mechanic, a nurse, a carpenter and a teacher.
Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Women of Utopia
results.creator_credit: Keith Gow, Elisabeth Knight and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “On the job (A)”.
With jokes and good humour, the Aboriginal women of Utopia cattle station show how they make their beautiful and exotic batik fabrics. Some of the women featured are Emily Ngwarai, Gloria Pitjara, Rosie Kunoth and Myrtle Pitjara. Also shows gathering/hunting of food and the cooking of it. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: A Ticket to ride
results.creator_credit: Keith Gow, Elisabeth Knight and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “On the job (A)”.
Explores the lives of four Aboriginal people, two women and two men, who have battled to attain high career achievements and top jobs in Australia. Features Wesley Lanhupuy, MLA Arnhem Land, N.T., Pat O’Shane, Secretary of N.S.W. Ministry of Aboriginal Affairs, Ernie Bridge, MLA Kimberley, W.A. and Marcia Langton, BA, 1st Class Hons, ANU.

results.title: Making perfect babies
results.creator_credit: Gwynne Basen, Mary Armstrong, Telefilms Canada, National Film Board of Canada, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and Cinefort
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “On the eighth day: perfecting Mother Nature”.
The day a baby can be genetically made-to-measure is still far away, but it is rapidly moving from the realm of fantasy to that of probability. “Making perfect babies” offers a critical examination of the genetic technology and its potential applications and raises important questions about why the technology is being developed and how it may affect the lives of women and society as a whole. Includes interviews with scientist and feminist Ruth Hubbard and disability activist Marsha Saxton.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gwynne Basen, Mary Armstrong, Telefilms Canada, National Film Board of Canada, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and Cinefort

results.title: Making babies
results.creator_credit: Gwynne Basen, Mary Armstrong, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, National Film Board of Canada and Cinefort
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “On the eighth day: perfecting Mother Nature”.
From a high tech marketplace in Paris, to the work being done at a fertility clinic in London, Ontario and a surrogacy centre in Los Angeles, “Making babies” takes a critical look at reproductive technology. Through interviews with doctors, drug salesmen, infertile women, surrogates and feminist critics like Gena Corea, the film explores the origins and application of the technology and the dangers it may pose to women and to society as a whole.

results.title: The Ground strokes with Billie Jean King on tennis
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “On Tennis”.
Very clearly Billie Jean King and others, explain and demonstrate the forehand and the backhand strokes of tennis.
